title: Dudley: I picked a fight with Trump because the Fed didn’t stand up for itself
text:
Bloomberg William Dudley, former president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, speaks during a television interview.

Ex-New York Fed President William Dudley said Wednesday that he wrote his controversial essay last month, in which he essentially picked a fight with President Donald Trump, because the central bank had not stood up for itself after months of critical tweets from the Oval Office.

Read: Fed should refuse to ‘play along’ with Trump’s trade war, Dudley says

“I wrote the article to express my concern that the president had placed the negative economic consequences of his trade war at the feet of the Fed and that Fed officials had not pushed back against this more forcibly,” Dudley wrote, in a follow-up essay, also published on Bloomberg.

“President Trump was shifting responsibility for the downside risks from his trade war onto the Fed,” Dudley said.

There was a risk that the Fed, by cutting interest rates, might encourage Trump to be even more aggressive on trade, he noted.

“I wanted the Fed to be more explicit that the greatest risk to the economy was the uncertainty created by the U.S. trade war with China. By making this clear, the Fed would increase President Trump’s stake in that downside risk. As a result, with more at stake, the president might be more attentive to the risks the trade war posed to the U.S. economy,” Dudley wrote.

Economists and the Fed community had reacted with astonishment to Dudley’s initial essay, which also argued the Fed consider the president’s bid for re-election in its interest-rate decision-making.

The Fed quickly distanced itself from the essay, issuing a rare public statement.

Former Treasury Secretary Larry Summers, who called Dudley a friend, said the former central banker had made a profound mistake with the first piece, and had been disloyal to the central bank.

See: Lawrence Summers slams Dudley for essay on Trump

Republicans had reacted with fury to the Dudley essay.

Sen. Thom Tillis, a Republican from North Carolina, urged the Senate Banking Committee to hold a hearing on the danger of the Fed meddling in the upcoming presidential election.

Dudley said he was just trying to be provocative in his comments about the election. He said he wasn’t suggesting the Fed should take sides in the contest.

“What the Fed does or doesn’t do can influence electoral outcomes, which in turn can have consequences for the economy and for monetary policy. But the Fed should never be motivated by political considerations or deliberately set monetary policy with the goal of influencing an election,” he said.

Trump has not responded to Dudley’s commentaries. The president recently raised eyebrows for calling Fed Chairman Jerome Powell an “enemy” for his interest-rate decisions, on par with China’s President Xi Yinping.

Read: Trump blasts Powell and Xi as ‘enemies’

Stocks were broadly higher Wednesday on hopes that political tensions in Hong Kong may ease. The S&P 500 index SPX, -2.17% closed up 31.51 points to 2,937.
